facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer gave award in Land Acquisition Case No. 51/LA/62 on March 25, 1969 based on market value as on October 1, 1955 plus 25% extra compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the Land Acquisition Officer gave his award in the Land Acquisition Case No. 51/LA/62 on March 25, 1969. The award was given on the basis of market value of the land as on October 1, 1955

facts.text: Bhopal was made Capital of Madhya Pradesh on November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged inter alia that Bhopal was made Capital of Madhya Pradesh on November 1, 1956. We were referred to the report of the States Reorganisation Commission, 1956.

facts.text: States Reorganisation Commission report submitted on September 30, 1955 proposing Jabalpur as capital.

anchor.surface_text: We were referred to the report of the States Reorganisation Commission, 1956. The new State, which can appropriately be described as Madhya Pradesh will be a companypact unit. ... This report was submitted on September 30, 955.

facts.text: On date of States Reorganisation Commission report, proposed capital was Jabalpur, no speculation in Bhopal land before announcement.

holdings.text: The classification between land in Bhopal area and other parts of the State is with reason and reasonable, and is for the purpose of enabling the State to acquire land at a reasonable price in Bhopal for the construction of the Capital.

anchor.surface_text: The classification between land in Bhopal area and other parts of the State is with reason and reasonable, and is for the purpose of enabling the State to acquire land at a reasonable price in Bhopal for the construction of the Capital. holdings.reasoning_summary: Intelligible differentia based on Bhopal's capital status justifies classification to prevent inflated prices and enable reasonable acquisition.

holdings.text: In our view, the amendments are not hit by Article 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable classification and absence of discrimination uphold validity against equal protection challenge.

holdings.text: There is no material on the record to show that on October 1, 1955, it was known that Bhopal may be the Capital of the State or that there was speculation in land because of this fact.

holdings.text: With respect, the High Court has not examined the question of the validity of the reason for fixing the relevant date as October 1, 1955.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower court failed to scrutinize basis for date selection despite lack of supporting material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical observation that fixing announcement date as cutoff is not perpetually applicable.

precedents.citation: Satish Kumar v. State of M.P.  1

anchor.surface_text: Satish Kumar v. State of M.P.  1 the Madhya Pradesh High Court upheld the validity of the impugned Act. The High Court justified the basis to differentiate the land located in Bhopal area thus In support of this difference, it has been averred in the return filed by the, State that in the reorganisation of the States, which was a political exigency, the fixation of the Capital at Bhopal was an accident number due to any economic or industrial reasons that when it was decided to locate the Capital of the State in the underdeveloped town, there was heavy speculation in land prices and that, therefore, these artificially inflated prices companyld number be taken as a proper basis for fixing the real market-value of the property.

precedents.case_name: Satish Kumar v. State of M.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Validity of the Land Acquisition (Madhya Pradesh Amendment) Act, 1959 against Article 14; classification of Bhopal area land reasonable due to speculation in prices after location of capital
precedents.cited_holding: When such speculative dealings occur it is not unreasonable and improper to compute the market-value of the land with reference to a date proximate to the date of acquisition so as to exclude speculative rise in determining the market value of the land.

anchor.surface_text: A.I.R. 1961 M.P. 280. occur it is number unreasonable and improper to companypute the market-value of the land with reference to a date proximate to the date of acquisition so as to exclude, speculative rise in determining the market value of the land. The classification between land in Bhopal area and other parts of the State is with reason and reasonable, and is for the purpose of enabling the State to acquire land at a reasonable price in Bhopal for the companystruction of the Capital. In our view, the amendments are number hit by Article 14 of the Constitution.
